"authors": ["Xu G", "Fields SK", "Laine C", "Veloski JJ", "Barzansky B", "Martini CJ"], "publication_type": {"ISSN": "0090-0036", "volume": "87", "type": "Journal Article", "pagination": null, "year": "1997 May", "cited_medium": null, "issn": null, "issue": "5", "title": "American journal of public health"}, "source": null, "language": "English"}, {"ids": {"embase": null, "doi": null, "scopus": null, "pubmed": "9228622"}, "title": "The National Health Service Corps: rural physician service and retention.", "abstract": null, "type": null, "authors": ["Cullen TJ", "Hart LG", "Whitcomb ME", "Rosenblatt RA"], "publication_type": {"ISSN": "0893-8652", "volume": "10", "type": "Journal Article", "pagination": null, "year": "1997 Jul-Aug", "cited_medium": null, "issn": null, "issue": "4", "title": "The Journal of the American Board of Family Practice"}, "source": null, "language": "English"}], "publication_info": {"volume": null, "pages": null, "journal": null, "issue": null, "year": null}, "title": "Financial incentives for return of service in underserved areas: a systematic review", "citation": null, "abstract": {"Methods": "We carried out systematic literature searches of PubMed, the Excerpta Medica database, the Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature, and the National Health Services Economic Evaluation Database for studies evaluating outcomes of financial-incentive programs published up to February 2009. To identify articles for review, we combined three search themes (health workers or students, underserved areas, and financial incentives). In the initial search, we identified 10,495 unique articles, 10,302 of which were excluded based on their titles or abstracts. We conducted full-text reviews of the remaining 193 articles and of 26 additional articles identified in reference lists or by colleagues. Forty-three articles were included in the final review. We extracted from these articles information on the financial-incentive programs (name, location, period of operation, objectives, target groups, definition of underserved area, financial incentives and obligation) and information on the individual studies (authors, publication dates, types of study outcomes, study design, sample criteria and sample size, data sources, outcome measures and study findings, conclusions, and methodological limitations). We reviewed program results (descriptions of recruitment, retention, and participant satisfaction), program effects (effectiveness in influencing health workers to provide care, to remain, and to be satisfied with work and personal life in underserved areas), and program impacts (effectiveness in influencing health systems and health outcomes).", "Conclusion": "Financial-incentive programs for return of service are one of the few health policy interventions intended to improve the distribution of human resources for health on which substantial evidence exists. However, the majority of studies are from the US, and only one study reports findings from a developing country, limiting generalizability. The existing studies show that financial-incentive programs have placed substantial numbers of health workers in underserved areas and that program participants are more likely than non-participants to work in underserved areas in the long run, even though they are less likely to remain at the site of original placement. As none of the existing studies can fully rule out that the observed differences between participants and non-participants are due to selection effects, the evidence to date does not allow the inference that the programs have caused increases in the supply of health workers to underserved areas.", "Results": "Of the 43 reviewed studies 34 investigated financial-incentive programs in the US. The remaining studies evaluated programs in Japan (five studies), Canada (two), New Zealand (one) and South Africa (one). The programs started between 1930 and 1998. We identified five different types of programs (service-requiring scholarships, educational loans with service requirements, service-option educational loans, loan repayment programs, and direct financial incentives). Financial incentives to serve for one year in an underserved area ranged from year-2000 United States dollars 1,358 to 28,470. All reviewed studies were observational. The random-effects estimate of the pooled proportion of all eligible program participants who had either fulfilled their obligation or were fulfilling it at the time of the study was 71% (95% confidence interval 60\u201380%). Seven studies compared retention in the same (underserved) area between program participants and non-participants. Six studies found that participants were less likely than non-participants to remain in the same area (five studies reported the difference to be statistically significant, while one study did not report a significance level); one study did not find a significant difference in retention in the same area. Thirteen studies compared provision of care or retention in any underserved area between participants and non-participants. Eleven studies found that participants were more likely to (continue to) practice in any underserved area (nine studies reported the difference to be statistically significant, while two studies did not provide the results of a significance test); two studies found that program participants were significantly less likely than non-participants to remain in any underserved area. Seven studies investigated the satisfaction of participants with their work and personal lives in underserved areas.", "Background": "In many geographic regions, both in developing and in developed countries, the number of health workers is insufficient to achieve population health goals. Financial incentives for return of service are intended to alleviate health worker shortages: A (future) health worker enters into a contract to work for a number of years in an underserved area in exchange for a financial pay-off."}, "authors": ["Till\u00a0B\u00e4rnighausen", "David\u00a0E\u00a0Bloom"], "keywords": null}

stay, hospital costs and patient outcomes", "citation": null, "abstract": {"Methods": "As participants, we considered hospitalized children and adults of every age and indication whose treatment involved the management strategy \"clinical pathways\". We include only randomised controlled trials (RCT) and controlled clinical trials (CCT), not restricted by language or country of publication. Single measures of continuous and dichotomous study outcomes were extracted from each study. A random effects meta-analysis was performed with untransformed and log transformed outcomes.", "Conclusion": "As a result of the relatively small number of studies meeting inclusion criteria, this evidence base is not conclusive enough to provide a replicable framework for all pathway strategies. Considering the clinical areas for implementation, clinical pathways seem to be effective especially for invasive care. When implementing clinical pathways, the decision makers need to consider the benefits and costs under different circumstances (e.g. market forces).", "Results": "In total 17 trials met inclusion criteria, representing 4,070 patients. The quality of the included studies was moderate and studies reporting economic data can be described by a very limited scope of evaluation. In general, the majority of studies reporting economic data (LOS and hospital costs) showed a positive impact. Out of 16 reporting effects on LOS, 12 found significant shortening. "Conclusions des auteurs": "Les cliniques pr\u00e9natales sp\u00e9cialis\u00e9es font maintenant partie des prestations de soins propos\u00e9es dans de nombreuses r\u00e9gions. Toute recherche future dans ce domaine devra inclure des crit\u00e8res de jugement psychologiques et s'int\u00e9resser aux prestations pr\u00e9f\u00e9r\u00e9es par les femmes. "Selection criteria": "All published, unpublished, and ongoing randomised controlled trials (including cluster-randomised trials) examining specialised compared with standard antenatal clinic care for women with a singleton pregnancy considered at high risk of preterm labour.", "Search methods": "We searched the Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth Group's Trials Register (30 June 2011).", "Main results": "We included three trials with 3400 women, all carried out in the USA. The interventions in the three trials differed.", "Objectives": "To assess using the best available evidence, the value of specialised antenatal clinics for women with a pregnancy at high risk of preterm delivery when compared with 'standard' antenatal clinics.", "\u8a33\u6ce8": "\u76e3\u3000\u3000\u8a33: \u6c5f\u85e4\u3000\u5b8f\u7f8e,2011.12.15", "\u691c\u7d22\u6226\u7565": "Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth Group's Trials Register\uff082011\u5e746\u670830\u65e5\uff09\u3092\u691c\u7d22\u3057\u305f\u3002", "Crit\u00e8res de s\u00e9lection": "Tous les essais contr\u00f4l\u00e9s randomis\u00e9s publi\u00e9s, non publi\u00e9s et en cours (y compris les essais randomis\u00e9s en groupe) comparant les cliniques pr\u00e9natales sp\u00e9cialis\u00e9es aux soins pr\u00e9nataux \u00ab\u00a0standard\u00a0\u00bb pour les femmes \u00e0 grossesse unique pr\u00e9sentant un risque \u00e9lev\u00e9 d'accouchement pr\u00e9matur\u00e9.", "Objectifs": "\u00c9valuer, en utilisant les meilleures preuves disponibles, l'int\u00e9r\u00eat des cliniques pr\u00e9natales sp\u00e9cialis\u00e9es comparativement aux cliniques pr\u00e9natales \u00ab\u00a0standard\u00a0\u00bb pour les femmes enceintes \u00e0 haut risque d'accouchement pr\u00e9matur\u00e9.", "R\u00e9sultats principaux": "Nous avons inclus trois essais portant sur 3 400 femmes, tous r\u00e9alis\u00e9s aux \u00c9tats-Unis. {"ids": {"pmid": "21901722", "episteId": "a11f9180a8eb7a558e7185febed6caaa091ae525", "doi": "10.1002/14651858.CD008451.pub2"}, "references": null, "publication_info": {"volume": null, "pages": null, "journal": null, "issue": null, "year": null}, "title": null, "citation": null, "abstract": null, "authors": null, "keywords": null}
{"ids": {"pmid": "21901704", "episteId": "59d9c8a5118fbfbd6f0dc1a987260f58b3d6e223", "doi": "10.1002/14651858.CD006413.pub2"}, "references": [], "publication_info": {"volume": null, "pages": null, "journal": null, "issue": null, "year": null}, "title": "Managerial supervision to improve primary health care in low- and middle-income countries", "citation": null, "abstract": {"Strat\u00e9gie de recherche documentaire": "Nous avons consult\u00e9 le registre Cochrane central des essais contr\u00f4l\u00e9s (CENTRAL), 2011, Num\u00e9ro 1, int\u00e9gr\u00e9 \u00e0 la Biblioth\u00e8que Cochrane www.thecochranelibrary.com, y compris le registre sp\u00e9cialis\u00e9 du groupe de revue Cochrane sur l'efficacit\u00e9 des pratiques et l'organisation des soins (EPOC) (recherche effectu\u00e9e le 10 mars 2011)\u00a0; MEDLINE, Ovid, de 1950 \u00e0 la 1\u00e8re semaine de mars 2011 (recherche effectu\u00e9e le 08 mars 2011)\u00a0; EMBASE, Ovid, de 1980 \u00e0 la semaine 12 de 2011 (recherche effectu\u00e9e le 08 mars 2011)\u00a0; CINAHL, Ebsco, de 1981 \u00e0 nos jours (recherche effectu\u00e9e le 10 mars 2011)\u00a0; LILACS, VHL (recherche effectu\u00e9e le 10 mars 2011).", "Recueil et analyse des donn\u00e9es": "Nous avons extrait les donn\u00e9es \u00e0 l'aide d'un formulaire pr\u00e9d\u00e9fini et \u00e9valu\u00e9 le risque de biais conform\u00e9ment aux crit\u00e8res d'EPOC en la mati\u00e8re. Les donn\u00e9es sont pr\u00e9sent\u00e9es sous forme narrative sans combiner les effets des r\u00e9sultats car les \u00e9tudes et les mesures de r\u00e9sultats \u00e9taient vari\u00e9es.", "Conclusions des auteurs": "On ignore si la supervision peut r\u00e9ellement avoir un effet positif substantiel sur la qualit\u00e9 des soins de sant\u00e9 primaires dans les pays \u00e0 faibles et moyens revenus. L'efficacit\u00e9 de la supervision \u00e0 long terme n'est pas \u00e9tablie.", "Data collection and analysis": "We extracted data using a predefined form and assessed for risk of bias using the EPOC risk of bias criteria. Data are presented in a narrative way without pooling the effects on the outcomes as studies and outcomes were diverse.", "Authors' conclusions": "It is uncertain whether supervision has a substantive, positive effect on the quality of primary health care in low- and middle-income countries. The long term effectiveness of supervision is unknown.", "Contexte": "Les travailleurs en soins de sant\u00e9 primaires (SSP) travaillent souvent seuls ou en situation d'isolement. La supervision administrative des soins de sant\u00e9 est recommand\u00e9e pour garantir la qualit\u00e9 des soins\u00a0; mais cela exige des superviseurs comp\u00e9tents, du temps et des ressources. Il est donc important d'\u00e9valuer les \u00e9ventuels b\u00e9n\u00e9fices de la supervision et la mani\u00e8re dont elle peut \u00eatre mise en \u0153uvre.", "Selection criteria": "Randomised controlled trials, controlled before-and-after studies, and interrupted time series studies, conducted in PHC in low- and middle-income countries. Supervision includes site visits from a central level of the health system, plus at least one supervisory activity. We excluded studies aimed solely at improving the clinical skills of PHC workers.", "Search methods": "We searched The Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) 2011, Issue 1, part of The Cochrane Library. www.thecochranelibrary.com, including the Cochrane Effective Practice and Organisation of Care (EPOC) Group Specialised Register (searched 10 March 2011); MEDLINE, Ovid 1950 to March Week 1 2011 (searched 08 March 2011); EMBASE, Ovid 1980 to 2011 Week 12 (searched 08 March 2011); CINAHL, Ebsco 1981 \u2013 present (searched 10 March 2011); LILACS, VHL (searched 10 March 2011).", "Main results": "Nine studies met the inclusion criteria: three compared supervision with no supervision, five compared enhanced supervision with routine supervision, and one study compared less intensive supervision with routine supervision. Most outcomes were scores relating to providers\u2019 practice, knowledge and provider or user satisfaction. The majority of the outcomes were measured within nine months after the interventions were introduced. In two studies comparing supervision with no supervision, small benefits on provider practice and knowledge were found. For methods of enhancing supervision, we identified five studies, and two studies of frequent supportive supervision demonstrated small benefits on workers performance. The one study examining the impact of less intensive supervision found no evidence that reducing the frequency of visits had any effect on the utilisation of services. The GRADE evidence quality for all comparisons and outcomes was \"low\" or \"very low\".", "Objectives": "To review the effects of managerial supervision of health workers to improve the quality of PHC (such as adherence to guidance or coverage of services) in low- and middle-income countries.", "Crit\u00e8res de s\u00e9lection": "Les essais contr\u00f4l\u00e9s randomis\u00e9s, les \u00e9tudes contr\u00f4l\u00e9es avant-apr\u00e8s et les \u00e9tudes de s\u00e9ries chronologiques interrompues men\u00e9es en SSP dans des pays \u00e0 faibles et moyens revenus. La supervision inclut des visites sur le site effectu\u00e9es par un service central du syst\u00e8me de sant\u00e9 avec au moins une activit\u00e9 de supervision. Les \u00e9tudes visant uniquement \u00e0 am\u00e9liorer les comp\u00e9tences cliniques des travailleurs en SSP ont \u00e9t\u00e9 exclues.", "Objectifs": "\u00c9tudier les effets de la supervision administrative des travailleurs de sant\u00e9 pour am\u00e9liorer la qualit\u00e9 des SSP (comme le respect des protocoles ou la couverture des services) dans les pays \u00e0 faibles et moyens revenus.", "R\u00e9sultats principaux": "Neuf \u00e9tudes \u00e9taient conformes aux crit\u00e8res d'inclusion\u00a0: trois \u00e9tudes comparaient une supervision \u00e0 l'absence de supervision, cinq \u00e9tudes comparaient une supervision accrue \u00e0 une supervision de routine et une \u00e9tude comparait une supervision moins intensive \u00e0 une supervision de routine. La plupart des mesures de r\u00e9sultats \u00e9taient les scores associ\u00e9s aux pratiques et connaissances des prestataires ou \u00e0 la satisfaction des prestataires ou des utilisateurs. La plupart \u00e9taient mesur\u00e9es dans les neuf mois suivant la mise en place des interventions. Dans deux \u00e9tudes comparant la supervision \u00e0 l'absence de supervision, de petits b\u00e9n\u00e9fices ont \u00e9t\u00e9 observ\u00e9s pour les pratiques et les connaissances des prestataires. Pour les m\u00e9thodes visant \u00e0 accro\u00eetre la supervision, nous avons identifi\u00e9 cinq \u00e9tudes, dont deux portant sur une supervision de soutien fr\u00e9quente rapportaient de petits b\u00e9n\u00e9fices pour les performances des travailleurs. La seule \u00e9tude examinant l'impact d'une supervision moins intensive n'apportait aucune preuve de l'impact de visites moins fr\u00e9quentes sur l'utilisation des services. La qualit\u00e9 des preuves pour toutes les comparaisons et mesures de r\u00e9sultats \u00e9tait \u00ab\u00a0faible\u00a0\u00bb ou \u00ab\u00a0tr\u00e8s faible\u00a0\u00bb."}, "authors": ["Xavier Bosch\u2010Capblanch", "Sajil Liaqat", "Paul Garner"], "keywords": null}
